title: YJIT-friendly structured code generator
description:
# Summary
Create a new code generator that emits native Ruby control flow (if/else, each blocks) instead of the state machine dispatch loop. This will enable YJIT to optimize our generated code effectively.

# Problem
Current RubyCompiler generates a `while true` + `case __pc__` state machine for any template with loops or conditionals. YJIT can't optimize this indirect dispatch pattern, so liquid_ruby+YJIT outperforms our compiled version.

# Solution
Implement a StructuredCompiler that:
1. Analyzes IL to recognize control flow patterns (for loops, if/else)
2. Generates native Ruby control flow (each blocks, if statements)
3. Enables YJIT to inline and specialize the generated code

# Success Criteria
- Benchmarks show compiled version faster than liquid_ruby with YJIT enabled
- All liquid-spec tests pass with structured compiler
- Falls back gracefully for complex patterns

# Benchmarks to Run

```bash
bundle exec rake bench

# With YJIT
RUBY_YJIT_ENABLE=1 bundle exec rake bench
```

title: Optimization policy framework
description:
Create a policy/configuration framework to control which optimizations run.

**Goals:**
- Allow enabling/disabling individual passes
- Support optimization levels (O0, O1, O2, O3)
- Enable debugging specific pass behavior
- Control tradeoffs (compile time vs runtime, code size vs speed)

**Policy decisions:**
- O0: No optimization (current default without optimize: true)
- O1: Fast, safe optimizations (const folding, dead code removal)
- O2: All current passes (default with optimize: true)
- O3: Aggressive (inlining, unrolling, may increase code size)

**Implementation:**
- OptimizationPolicy class with pass enable/disable
- Pass ordering/dependency management
- Per-pass configuration (e.g., unroll threshold, inline size limit)
- Debug mode to dump IL after each pass

**Integration:**
- Wrap existing optimize() method
- New API: compile(optimization_level: 2)
- Tests should pass: rake test && rake spec

```
[else body]  # at else_label

```

# Generated Ruby
```ruby
if __truthy__(condition)
  # then body
else

end
```

- [ ] Generate Ruby if statements
- [ ] Handle elsif chains (multiple conditions)

Currently catching StandardError in render methods to handle drop method errors, which is too broad. Should have:

title: Loop unrolling pass
description:
Implement loop unrolling for small, bounded for loops.

**Target loops:**
- FOR loops with statically known iteration count
- Small iteration count (e.g., ≤4 iterations)
- No early exits (break) 

**Benefits:**
- Eliminates loop overhead (FOR_INIT, FOR_NEXT, FOR_END)
- Enables further optimizations on unrolled body
- Particularly valuable for small array iterations

**Algorithm:**
- Detect FOR_INIT with constant range or small array
- Duplicate loop body n times with loop variable substituted
- Remove FOR_INIT/FOR_NEXT/FOR_END instructions

**Considerations:**
- forloop object must be correctly emulated
- Code size increase vs performance tradeoff
- Consider unroll factor configuration

**Integration:**
- Add as optimization pass in compiler.rb
- Tests should pass: rake test && rake spec

title: Value numbering pass
description:
Implement global value numbering (GVN) to identify equivalent computations and eliminate redundant ones.

**Core algorithm:**
- Assign unique value numbers to expressions
- Expressions with same inputs get same value number
- Replace redundant computations with cached values

**Key patterns to optimize:**
- Repeated FIND_VAR for same variable → reuse
- Repeated CALL_FILTER with same inputs → reuse  
- Repeated arithmetic expressions → reuse

**Implementation:**
- Build value number table during forward pass
- Track which temps hold which value numbers
- Replace redundant expressions with LOAD_TEMP

**Dependencies:**
- Effect analysis (to know which operations are pure)

**Integration:**
- Add as optimization pass in compiler.rb
- Tests should pass: rake test && rake spec

title: Global linear scan register allocator
description: Implement global linear scan register allocation for the RubyCompiler backend. Assign virtual registers to physical locals/temps, minimizing spills and reloads. Requires liveness analysis across the full instruction stream.

title: Skip state machine for linear templates
description:
**Problem:** Even simple templates like `{{ name }}` generate a full state machine with `while true; case __pc__; when 0; ...` pattern, adding overhead for the common case.

**Proposed improvement:** Detect templates without control flow (no jumps/labels) and generate straight-line code instead:

```ruby
# Current
__pc__ = 0
while true
  case __pc__
  when 0
    __output__ << "Hello "
    __output__ << (__v__ = __scope__.lookup("name"); ...)
    break
  else
    break
  end
end

# Proposed
__output__ << "Hello "
__output__ << (__v__ = __scope__.lookup("name"); ...)
```

**Impact:** Eliminate dispatch overhead for ~60% of templates (those without control flow).

**Profile evidence:** State machine dispatch visible in hot path.

**Implementation notes:**
- Add IL analysis pass to detect linear templates (no JUMP, LABEL, etc.)
- Add alternate code generation path in ruby_compiler.rb
- Benchmark before/after
close_reason: Feature already implemented - generate_ruby_body correctly uses generate_straight_line for linear templates (no jumps/control flow). Fixed two unrelated bugs found during investigation: added missing find_max_temp_index method and initialized @hoist_temp_counter.

title: Compiled: render for loop doesn't iterate over Drops with each

close_reason: Fixed render for loop iteration in ruby_compiler.rb. Changed generate_partial_call to match VM semantics: Arrays iterate, Ranges iterate for render (not include), enumerable Drops iterate, nil renders once with named args only, scalars render once with that value. Also fixed render with when implicit value is nil - named args now take precedence for isolated render. Reduced test failures from 21 to 6 (remaining failures are unrelated error message formatting issues).

title: StructuredCompiler: Break/continue support

# Task
Support break and continue statements in for loops.

# Challenge
Ruby's break/next work differently than Liquid's:
- Liquid break/continue use interrupts that can propagate through includes
- Ruby break/next are lexical

# Options
1. Use catch/throw for break/continue
2. Use a flag variable checked each iteration
3. Limit structured compilation to loops without break/continue

# Deliverables
- [ ] Detect break/continue in loop bodies
- [ ] Implement chosen strategy
- [ ] Test break in nested loops
- [ ] Test continue behavior

title: VM interpreter optimization: eliminate per-instruction overhead
Escape analysis and scalar replacement pass
description:
Implement escape analysis to determine if objects escape their defining scope, enabling scalar replacement.

**Escape analysis:**
- Track if hash/array values escape (passed to filters, partials, output)
- Non-escaping aggregates can be decomposed into scalars

**Scalar replacement:**
- Replace non-escaping BUILD_HASH with individual scalar values
- Replace hash[key] lookups with direct scalar access
- Eliminates hash allocation and lookup overhead

**Key patterns:**
- {% assign h = 'a' | something | hash_filter %}
- If h only used locally with known keys, replace with scalars

**Considerations:**
- Liquid hashes are relatively rare - measure impact
- Must handle dynamic key access conservatively

**Dependencies:**
- Effect analysis (to track escaping through filters)

**Integration:**
- Add as optimization pass in compiler.rb
- Tests should pass: rake test && rake spec

title: Inlining pass
description:
Implement inlining for render/include partials when beneficial.

**Target scenarios:**
- Small partials (below size threshold)
- Frequently called partials
- Partials with constant arguments

**Benefits:**
- Eliminates partial call overhead
- Enables cross-partial optimization
- Constant propagation into partial body

**Algorithm:**
- Identify RENDER_PARTIAL/INCLUDE_PARTIAL with resolvable template
- If partial small enough, inline its IL
- Rename labels to avoid conflicts
- Adjust scope handling (PUSH_SCOPE/POP_SCOPE)

**Considerations:**
- Must handle recursive partials (don't inline)
- Variable scoping differences between render vs include
- Code size increase tradeoff
- May need partial lookup at compile time

**Note:** CONST_RENDER/CONST_INCLUDE already exist - this extends that

**Integration:**
- Add as optimization pass in compiler.rb
- Tests should pass: rake test && rake spec

title: Store and load forwarding pass
description:
Implement store-to-load and load-to-load forwarding to eliminate redundant memory operations.

**Store-to-load forwarding:**
- When loading a value just stored, use the stored value directly
- Pattern: ASSIGN x, val; ... FIND_VAR x → use val directly

**Load-to-load forwarding:**  
- When loading same variable twice, reuse first load
- Pattern: FIND_VAR x; ... FIND_VAR x → LOAD_TEMP

**Key considerations:**
- Must track aliasing (what could have modified the variable)
- Invalidate on: PUSH_SCOPE, POP_SCOPE, CALL_FILTER with side effects
- Respect control flow boundaries

**Dependencies:**
- Effect analysis (to know what modifies variables)

**Integration:**
- Add as optimization pass in compiler.rb
- Tests should pass: rake test && rake spec

title: Global linear scan register allocator
description:
Implement linear scan register allocation for temp slots.

**Problem:**
- Current STORE_TEMP/LOAD_TEMP uses arbitrary temp slot numbers
- No coordination between different optimization passes
- May use more temps than necessary

**Linear scan algorithm:**
- Build live ranges for all temps
- Sort by start position
- Allocate in linear order, spilling least-recently-used when needed
- Minimize total temp slots used

**Benefits:**
- Reduces VM temp array size
- Better cache locality
- Enables Ruby compiler to use fewer local variables

**Implementation:**
- Liveness analysis pass (forward + backward)
- Build live intervals
- Linear scan allocation with spill handling
- Rewrite temp slot numbers

**Integration:**
- Add as optimization pass in compiler.rb
- Run late in pipeline (after other passes add temps)
- Tests should pass: rake test && rake spec

title: Use Set for control_flow_boundary? lookup
description:
**Problem:** `control_flow_boundary?` uses `case/when` for 14 opcodes, called per-instruction during optimization passes.

**Profile evidence:** 3.8% of compile time.

**Proposed improvement:** Use a frozen set for O(1) lookup:

```ruby
CONTROL_FLOW_OPCODES = [
  IL::LABEL, IL::JUMP, IL::JUMP_IF_TRUE, # ...
].to_set.freeze

def control_flow_boundary?(inst)
  CONTROL_FLOW_OPCODES.include?(inst[0])
end
```

**Implementation notes:**
- Identify where control_flow_boundary? is defined
- Replace case/when with Set lookup
- Ensure set is frozen for thread safety
close_reason: Replaced case/when with CONTROL_FLOW_OPCODES.to_set.freeze for O(1) lookup instead of O(n) sequential case matching

title: StructuredCompiler: For loop code generation
description:
# Task
Generate native Ruby each blocks for Liquid for loops.

# IL Pattern to Recognize
```
FIND_VAR "items"
JUMP_IF_EMPTY end
FOR_INIT "item", ...
PUSH_SCOPE
PUSH_FORLOOP
FOR_NEXT continue, break
[body]
JUMP FOR_NEXT
[cleanup]
```

# Generated Ruby
```ruby
__coll__ = scope.lookup("items")
if __coll__.is_a?(Array) && !__coll__.empty?
  scope.push_scope
  forloop = ForloopDrop.new(...)
  __coll__.each_with_index do |item, idx|
    forloop.index0 = idx
    scope.assign_local("item", item)
    # body
  end
  scope.pop_scope
end
```

# Deliverables
- [ ] Detect FOR_INIT...FOR_END pattern in IL
- [ ] Generate each_with_index block
- [ ] Handle forloop drop (index, first, last, length)
- [ ] Handle reversed loops
- [ ] Handle limit/offset

title: Escape analysis & scalar replacement
description: Implement escape analysis to identify objects/values that don't escape their defining scope. Replace non-escaping aggregates with scalar values to eliminate allocation and enable register allocation of their fields.

title: Cache find_max_temp_index result
description:
**Problem:** `find_max_temp_index` iterates all instructions and is called multiple times during compilation.

**Profile evidence:** 6.3% of compile time.

**Proposed improvement:** Compute once and cache, or track incrementally during IL generation:

```ruby
# Track during IL building
@max_temp_index = -1
def emit_store_temp(idx)
  @max_temp_index = [@max_temp_index, idx].max
  emit(IL::STORE_TEMP, idx)
end
```

**Implementation notes:**
- Option A: Cache in IL object after first computation
- Option B: Track incrementally during IL generation
- Option B preferred if IL building is well-encapsulated
close_reason: Eliminated redundant find_max_temp_index calls by returning updated temp_counter from value_number_block. Reduces O(n*b) scans to O(n) where n=instructions, b=blocks.

title: Dead store elimination pass
description:
Implement dead store elimination (DSE) to remove stores to variables that are never read.

**Core algorithm:**
- Backward dataflow analysis

title: Skip ErrorMarker check for safe operations
description:
**Problem:** Every output expression includes `__v__.is_a?(LiquidIL::ErrorMarker) ? __v__.to_s : ...` even for operations that can't produce errors.

**Current code:**
```ruby
__output__ << (__v__ = __lookup_property__(__t0__, "title"); __v__.is_a?(LiquidIL::ErrorMarker) ? __v__.to_s : LiquidIL::Utils.output_string(__v__))
```

**Proposed improvement:** Track which operations can produce errors at compile time:

```ruby
# Property lookups never produce ErrorMarker
__output__ << LiquidIL::Utils.output_string(__lookup_property__(__t0__, "title"))

# Filter calls can produce ErrorMarker - keep the check
__output__ << (__v__ = __call_filter__(...); __v__.is_a?(LiquidIL::ErrorMarker) ? __v__.to_s : LiquidIL::Utils.output_string(__v__))
```

**Implementation notes:**
- Audit which IL operations can produce ErrorMarker
- Add metadata to IL or track in code generator
- Generate simplified output code for safe operations
close_reason: Implemented can_error tracking in build_expression_chain. Operations without filters (lookups, property access) now generate direct LiquidIL::Utils.output_string() calls without the ErrorMarker type check. Filter calls retain the check since they can produce runtime errors.
